ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We focused primarily on understanding existing historiography, how the memories of Vichy have evolved and been commemorated/represented in post-war French politics, and how different historians have approached distinctions between collaboration and resistance, and we wrote 25-page term papers.

This is a comprehensive class on the history of Vichy France: Resistance, collaboration, the politics, culture, economics, and so on, and so forth. You will learn a great deal about the broader Second World War in Europe, and about the context for the War in French history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course would have been great in-person but definitely suffered a bit in the Zoom environment. The readings were compelling and informative (make sure to leave a good chunk of time each week to get through them!), the final paper was a daunting but meaningful capstone to the semester (although the lack of intermediate deadlines meant that setting deadlines along the way was completely self-imposed), and our conversations were generally interesting. That said, it's hard for a conversation to feel free-flowing over Zoom, and it was often tough to gauge who was raising their hand or identify when students wanted to comment while Prof. Merriman was continuing his train of thought. I think a lot of these dynamics wouldn't have been a problem in-person, but it made our conversations feel stilted and not super organic. Prof. Merriman would often pose a new question or move on when there were still students attempting to jump in; this pattern certainly was a result of Zoom and not intentional, but it felt like we never really got into a conversational groove before switching direction. I would have also loved a stronger sense of community in our class; given how niche the subject is, I would have loved to get a sense of everyone else's interests, especially during such a socially isolated semester! Overall, I'd take this class in-person if you're interested in the content; I still got a lot out of it but felt like a piece of the experience was missing.
The greatest strength of this class by far is Professor Merriman. His ability to tell a story based on his incredible memory and wealth of knowledge makes the two hour session fly by!
It is a wonderful seminar with excellent readings and films, and an amazing instructor to match! Strengths include the instructor, syllabus, and other people in the course. There are no weaknesses.

Strengths: John is one of the kindest, most fun professors I've had at Yale. Even online, the classroom atmosphere was welcoming and fun... It felt like we were just having an academic discussion among friends, rather than in a college course (and a departmental seminar at that). And with this great atmosphere, the discussions were very interesting and informative! The questions John asked to prompt our discussion were both broad and specific, so there was something for everyone to respond to, whether you wanted to have a more directed discussion or wanted to talk about your own takeaways from the reading. With a combination of the books we read, our class discussions, and our final research paper, I learned a ton. John knows so much about France, especially Vichy, so we always got extra tidbits of information. Sometimes our discussions would get a little distracted and tangential to the original topic, but I count that as a strength because that made class even more interesting, engaging, and feeling like a great chat rather than a forced classroom discussion. I liked that we only had one paper, but it was a long research paper, so we could really dive into our chosen topic in-depth. Overall, I absolutely LOVED this class.

Weaknesses: Some of the readings/books were a bit long, but I suppose that just comes with the history departmental seminars. The class was somewhat laid-back, which I think was a strength, but if you don't like more loose or laid-back teaching styles, you might consider this to be in the weaknesses category. The only other thing was that the final paper was 80% of our grade, which can really make or break your grade. However, because we only had one long paper I can't think of any way this could be altered, other than giving participation more weight.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There wasn't a mutually agreed-upon way to jump into the conversation -- some students unmuted and started talking right away, while others waited to be called on. I think that clear expectations at the beginning of the semester of how conversation should be structured over Zoom would have been helpful.
The course transitioned completely smoothly online. While we all would've rather been together in person, the seminar over Zoom was the next best thing during the pandemic.
It's just really hard to have good discussion over Zoom. Hopefully this class can be an in-person seminar moving forward.
With the discussion format, we just used Zoom as normal, and it's great for a discussion. The only downside was we didn't always know whether to just unmute or to raise our hands.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'd recommend this course to another student if you are interested in the material and ready to do some heavy lifting for the term paper. It was definitely a course that occupied as much time as I wanted to give it; I felt like I got out what I put in and am glad to have taken it.

Absolutely, I took this class as a senior to try out a history seminar before I graduated and it was truly one of the best courses Ive ever taken at Yale. Be prepared to do a lot of reading though, you really get out of it what you put in!
Yes, without hesitation. This is one of the best classes you'll take at Yale whether or not you're a history major.
Yes! If you like history or just want to hear great stories, take it.

Absolutely, but only if they are looking for a very specific type of class. Professor Merriman frequently takes up a lot of the class time with stories about France or other historians he knows, which I always found fascinating and fun, but if someone wants a class where the professor is laser-focused on the readings, this is not it. This class is basically a weekly book club (reading is a full book on Vichy France most weeks) with a 15-25 page paper at the end as the only assignment. Take the class for Merriman, stay for his wine suggestions.

If you like history, even if you're not so sure about the topic of Vichy France, I would recommend this class just to have John as your professor! And if you want to learn a lot about France under the German occupation, definitely.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
